content.raw:
One other issue this is going to raise: We're changing the convention for the CMake variables which get generated by find_package. For example, `find_package(ignition-math3)` would now generate `ignition-math3_LIBRARIES` and `ignition-math3_INCLUDE_DIRS` instead of `IGNITION-MATH_LIBRARIES` and `IGNITION-MATH_INCLUDE_DIRS`. This means that dependent libraries will need to update their use of cmake before they can be compiled against the revised version of `ignition-math3`.

This is a somewhat painful change, but it's necessary to allow different major versions of an ignition project to work alongside each other.

Edit: To save ourselves a large amount of pain, we could choose to only adopt `ignition-cmake` on unreleased versions of packages, so that we don't harm any downstream dependents.

content.raw:
Whether or not we want it to occur in an ignition project, it could easily happen in a more complex build system. For example, suppose an ignition user has a repo where they're maintaining a set of plugins, and one of the plugins depends on `ignition-math3` while another depends on `ignition-math4`. If we don't distinguish the cmake variables based on their major version, those variables could overwrite each other in the user's build system, and then the targets of their plugins won't get the correct information to build against.

Edit: Granted, the world would be a better place if everyone used imported targets, but I think it will take time before that practice is widely adopted, and I don't think we're in a position to impose it on users.

content.raw:
~~We're already versioning all include paths, which is extremely important just to be able to install multiple major versions at a time. It would be extremely harmful to us (as developers) as well as end users to not use that practice.~~ (Edit: I probably misinterpreted "version all include paths". I agree that we should avoid having versions explicitly in the header paths that get included in source files. As [Shane already broke down](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/1/first-version-of-ignition-cmake/diff#comment-46067933) it would be necessary if we wanted one target (along with the interfaces of its dependencies) to support multiple major versions, but I think it is fair to rule out that use case unless it becomes unavoidable.)

Versioning namespaces would only be necessary if we wanted a single target to be able to build against multiple versions of the same library, which is certainly something that would be unusual, and which I would not at all encourage, because that would hurt the process of migrating dependent code to new versions.

As far as versioning the cmake variables is concerned, I don't think it's an unusual practice at all. In fact, what's less usual is having inconsistency between the name of the package and the variables it produces. E.g. `find_package(ignition-math3)` should conventionally produce variables of the form `ignition-math3_FOUND` (which is auto-generated by cmake), `ignition-math3_LIBRARIES`, `ignition-math3_INCLUDE_DIRS`, etc. Instead, our setup up until now has produced variables of the form `IGNITION-MATH_LIBRARIES` and `IGNITION-MATH_INCLUDE_DIRS`, which is inconsistent with the package name. If we want all uppercase variables, we should also make the package name all uppercase.

For one example of a notable library exercising this practice, `Qt` made the switch from versionless variables to versioned variables, as you can see [in this post](https://www.kdab.com/using-cmake-with-qt-5/). Granted, their system also involves module names which aren't exactly relevant to us, but the versioned variable concept is still there. I can look for more examples if desired. Admittedly, this may be a relatively new practice, but it has emerged out of necessity as people realize that sufficiently complex projects are likely to run into this issue.

I'm not really clear on what the disadvantage of versioning the variables would be. Is the hope that keeping the variables unversioned would reduce friction in migrating to a new version? There are some pretty simple solutions to that, like using a cmake variable to specify which version you are using, so you only have to specify the desired version once.

It sounds like "supporting two major versions" you're talking about is two major versions in the same target, while @mxgrey appears to be talking about two major version in the same cmake project. Please correct me if I've misunderstood.

Versioning include paths `#include <ignition/math4/math.hh>`

 * Same project
    * Not necessary. Since include paths are propagated from the linked targets. `#include <ignition/math.hh>` will be version 4 if you `target_link_libraries(ignition-math4)`.
* Same target
    * Necessary only if two things you depend on have used ignition-math in the public API (ex: `target_link_libraries(my_target PUBLIC ignition-math4)`

Versioning c++ namespace

* Same project
    * Not necessary, as long as no one accidentally links both major versions into the same target
* Same target
    * Always necessary


Side note, IIRC versioning the C++ namespace is required anyways to release a version of gazebo greater than 7 into ros, but I don't remember why. Do you?

Ignition Transport needs to create some auxiliary binary files for running some of the integration tests. However, these files shouldn't be part of the test suite executed when running `make test`. This is what I'm doing in the Ignition Transport branch that I'm testing for integrating this pull request:

```
#!python

set(auxiliary_files
  fastPub_aux
  pub_aux
  pub_aux_throttled
  scopedTopicSubscriber_aux
  twoProcessesPublisher_aux
  twoProcessesPubSubSubscriber_aux
  twoProcessesSrvCallReplier_aux
  twoProcessesSrvCallReplierIncreasing_aux
  twoProcessesSrvCallWithoutInputReplier_aux
  twoProcessesSrvCallWithoutInputReplierIncreasing_aux
  twoProcessesSrvCallWithoutOutputReplier_aux
  twoProcessesSrvCallWithoutOutputReplierIncreasing_aux
)

# Build the auxiliary files.
foreach(AUX_EXECUTABLE ${auxiliary_files})
  ign_add_executable(INTEGRATION_${AUX_EXECUTABLE} ${AUX_EXECUTABLE}.cc)

  # Include the interface directories that we always need.
  ign_target_interface_include_directories(INTEGRATION_${AUX_EXECUTABLE}
    ${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME})

  # Link the libraries that we always need.
  target_link_libraries(INTEGRATION_${AUX_EXECUTABLE}
    PRIVATE
      ${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME}
      gtest
      pthread
  )
endforeach(AUX_EXECUTABLE)
```

I'm wondering if it would be possible to integrate this use case within `ign_build_tests` with yet another test type.

Maybe a clean approach would be to have

`ign_build_executables([PREFIX <prefix>] SOURCES <sources> [...other arguments that are provided by ign_build_tests...])`

which does not make the executables part of the test suite. We could then have `ign_build_tests(~)`  invoke `ign_build_executables(~)` and then handle the additional work of adding each test to the test suite, plus linking to `gtest`, `gtest-main`, and whatever other setup is specific to the tests.

content.raw:
The generator expressions are evaluated at configure time, and they are not contained in the generate imported targets. 
In particular the imported target generated by [`install(EXPORT ...)`](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.5/command/install.html#installing-targets)  only contain the include directories specified in the `INSTALL_INTERFACE` generator expression. 
The only imported targets that contain the directories specified in the `BUILD_INTERFACE` generator expression are the one generated with the [`export(EXPORT ...)`](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.5/command/export.html) command. As mentioned in the CMake documentation: 

> The file created by this command (i.e. `export(EXPORT ...)`) is specific to the build tree and should never be installed.

So we will always distribute the targets created by the `install(EXPORT ...)` command, that are not concern by the  `BUILD_INTERFACE` generator expression .
content.html:
The generator expressions are evaluated at configure time, and they are not contained in the generate imported targets. In particular the imported target generated by install(EXPORT ...) only contain the include directories specified in the INSTALL_INTERFACE generator expression. The only imported targets that contain the directories specified in the BUILD_INTERFACE generator expression are the one generated with the export(EXPORT ...) command. As mentioned in the CMake documentation:

The file created by this command (i.e. export(EXPORT ...)) is specific to the build tree and should never be installed.

So we will always distribute the targets created by the install(EXPORT ...) command, that are not concern by the BUILD_INTERFACE generator expression .

Now that the symbol visibility is not an issue anymore, it would be nice to offer to the user the possibility to compile the library as `STATIC` if desired. 
This is typically done by removing the `SHARED` from the `add_library` call and by respecting the [`BUILD_SHARED_LIBS`](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.5/variable/BUILD_SHARED_LIBS.html) CMake variable, and setting its default value to `ON` to preserve the same default behavior of building a `SHARED` lib.

See https://github.com/robotology/how-to-export-cpp-library/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L48 for an example. 

This is particularly useful to simplify writing [`vcpkg`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vcpkg) ports of ignition libraries, as `vcpkg` explicitly support both static and shared triplets: https://vcpkg.readthedocs.io/en/latest/users/triplets/ .

content.raw: Feel free to ignore this if it's answered further below, but is there some macro creating Export.hhs using GenerateExportHeader? What about an ignition project with  multiple libraries? I believe each library will need it's own export header and macro.
content.html: Feel free to ignore this if it's answered further below, but is there some macro creating Export.hhs using GenerateExportHeader? What about an ignition project with multiple libraries? I believe each library will need it's own export header and macro.

content.raw:
Yes, `Export.hh` gets auto-generated. To be more specific, we configure `Export.hh` from the file `ign-cmake/cmake/Export.hh.in` so that we have a file which presents the macros cleanly with in-header documentation, and then `GenerateExportHeader` is used to produce a file `detail/Export.hh` which is used by `Export.hh` to provide the actual implementation of the macros.

Currently many of the macros and functions in `ign-cmake` are specifically designed to only produce one designated "ignition" library per project (not counting auxiliary libraries which may be used for testing or example purposes). I *believe* cmake supports the ability to have "sub-projects" within a single build system, so if we wanted multiple ignition libraries in one cmake "project", we may be able to handle them as sub-projects. That being said, I haven't tested that use case. It wouldn't shock me if we needed a considerable redesign of `ign-cmake` in order to support multiple ignition libraries per project, but I decided not to take that possibility into consideration since it seemed more important to me that we have something working soon for the setup we have now, and then we can bump the version and do a redesign on `ign-cmake` if we decide we care about broader use cases in the future.
